senses.de: The time between the initiation and completion of a production process or the delivery of a product or service.
senses.ex: The lead time for custom-made furniture is usually eight weeks.
cl: the lead time for the project

Tips.title: Manufacturing
Tips.description: Lead time is crucial in manufacturing to ensure timely delivery of products and efficient inventory management.
Tips.example: The factory needs to shorten its lead time to meet the increasing demand.

Tips.title: Project Management
Tips.description: In project management, lead time is used to schedule tasks and estimate project completion dates.
Tips.example: The project manager factored in the lead time for procuring materials when creating the project timeline.

Tips.title: Supply Chain Management
Tips.description: Lead time is a critical factor in supply chain management as it affects inventory levels and customer satisfaction.
Tips.example: The company's long lead times for raw materials caused production delays.

Turnaround time.wordDefinition: While both refer to a duration, turnaround time focuses on the time taken to complete a process and return it to the originator, often involving a service or repair. Lead time, on the other hand, focuses on the time from initiation to delivery, particularly in production or supply chain contexts.

Delivery time.wordDefinition: Delivery time is specifically the time it takes for a product or service to reach the customer after it's ready.  Lead time encompasses the entire process before delivery, including production or preparation.

Processing time.wordDefinition: Processing time refers solely to the duration of a specific process within a larger sequence. Lead time can include multiple processing times along with other delays.
